tutorial.title: Introduction to Modules
tutorial.descriptionContent: Introduction to splitting your code into modules

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we write bigger programs, we often have to rewrite code that performs specific operations.

For example, say that for a game, you have to rewrite the code that makes a character jump. Generally, we use functions to reuse the code.

lessons.title: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
But too many functions can make the code lengthy and hard to read. In this case, we can put the functions in modules to group them better.

Modules allow you to break your code into different code files. This allows for easier management.

lessons.title: Modules
lessons.interactiveContent:
Modules are files that contain variables, functions, etc. Here, we've created mod.js as a module. You can have as many modules as you want.

Make sure to pick const.

lessons.title: Export
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use variables from a module, we have to export them using the export keyword and specify default to export only one object.

Make sure to pick default.

lessons.title: Import
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use a variable from a module in a different file, we need to first import it using import from. Here, we'll import pi from mod.js.

Make sure to pick import, followed by from.

lessons.title: Import - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use ./ to specify the relative path. In this case, ./mod.js tells JavaScript to look for the file mod.js in the current folder.

Make sure to pick ", followed by ./mod.js, and finally ".

lessons.title: Use imported variable
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now that we've imported the variable, we can use it. Let's display the value of pi in the console.

Make sure to type pi.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does a module contain?

Variables, functions, etcFiles

Variables, functions, etc.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following syntax for a default export is correct?

export default var1default export var1

export default var1.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with the given import statement?

It doesn't specify the file nameimport should come after var1

It doesn't specify the file name.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What would be the output when the file script.js is executed?

11Error

Make sure to pick 11.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a variable pi that stores 3.14.

Make sure to pick const, followed by pi, and finally ;.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use default export to export pi.

Make sure to pick export, followed by default, and finally pi.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import pi from mod.js.

Make sure to pick import pi.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the value of pi in the console.

Make sure to pick console followed by . and then log, (, pi, ).

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Modules are not just constrained to variables. We can also import functions from modules to use in a different file.

lessons.title: Coding the function 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Firstly, let's code the function that we'll export. The function is an arrow function with two parameters stored in the reminder variable.

Make sure to pick => followed by { and then }, ;.

lessons.title: Coding the function 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
The function will return a reminder that will contain the message along with the reason. Adding parameters helps in customizing the message.

Make sure to pick const, followed by return, and finally ;.

lessons.title: Default export
lessons.interactiveContent:
Whenever we have to export only one object from a module, we use default export. Here also, we'll use export default to export reminder.

Make sure to pick export, followed by default.

lessons.title: Import
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, to use the function in another file, we need to import it.

Make sure to pick import followed by reminder and then from, "./mod.js".

lessons.title: Use imported function
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's display Wake up.Time for coding in the console. For this, we'll use Wake up. and coding as parameter values.

Make sure to pick console, followed by ., and finally log.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Modules can only export variables. True or false?

FalseTrue

Make sure to pick False.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is a default export?

The type of export used to export a single elementThe type of export used to export multiple elements

The type of export used to export a single element.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is the correct way to export a function?

export default funcexport default func()

export default func.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which one of the following is more suitable to be in a module?

A function that returns a user's pet's nameA function that returns custom notifications

A function that returns custom notifications.

lessons.title: Question 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with the given code that has imported a function from a module?

The parentheses of the function call are missingThe import statement is wrong

The parentheses of the function call are missing.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Store an arrow function in reminder that takes two parameters, message and event.

Make sure to pick ( followed by ) and then =>, {, }, ;.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the missing keyword to return message + reason.

Make sure to type return.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Export reminder using a default export.

Make sure to type export default.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import reminder from mod.js.

Make sure to pick import, followed by from.

lessons.title: Example 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the reminder function and display the result.

Make sure to pick reminder, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
We learned about how to export one element using default export. However, in a module, we might have a lot of elements to export.

To export multiple elements from a module, we use named exports. Let's find out more!

lessons.title: Elements to export
lessons.interactiveContent:
Say that we have a variable and a function to export from a file.

Make sure to pick const, followed by function.

lessons.title: Named export
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use a named export, just put export before the objects that you want to export.

Make sure to pick export, followed by export.

lessons.title: Import multiple elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, to import multiple elements from the module in a different file, we need to use {} around their names and separate them using ,.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Use imported elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Having imported what we needed, let's display it in the console. We'll call the function with values flight, Vienna, New York.

Make sure to pick query, followed by flight.

lessons.title: One line export
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another way to do a named export is to export all the elements at once at the bottom using export and curly braces.

Make sure to pick export, followed by {, and finally }.

lessons.title: Renaming
lessons.interactiveContent:
You can also rename your exports using the as keyword! Then you can import the variables using the new names.

Make sure to type as.

lessons.title: Renaming in import
lessons.interactiveContent:
Alternatively, you can rename elements in the import statement in another file.

Make sure to pick flight, followed by as, and finally airline.

lessons.title: Default and named export
lessons.interactiveContent:
A module can have both named exports and a default export at the same time.

Make sure to pick export, followed by default.

lessons.title: Default and named export - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The default export is imported without curly braces, while the named exports are imported inside curly braces, as we have seen before.

Make sure to pick query, followed by flight.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
An engineer wants to export 3 elements from a module. Which of the following exports should they use?

Named exportDefault export

Named export.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with the given code?

Missing {} in export statementCan't export variables all at once

Missing {} in export statement.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with the given code?

The export statement should come at the end after variable declarationCan't export multiple variables

The export statement should come at the end after variable declaration.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the correct syntax for importing multiple elements?

import {obj1, obj2...} from filenameimport obj1, obj2... filename

import {obj1, obj2...} from filename.

lessons.title: Question 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where can you rename named exports?

In the export and import statementOnly in the export statement

In the export and import statement.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use named export to export flight and query.

Make sure to pick export, followed by export.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import flight and query from mod.js.

Make sure to pick import followed by { and then }, from.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the function query in console.log.

Make sure to type query.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Export flight and query in a single line.

Make sure to type export.

lessons.title: Example 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Rename query as ticket in the import statement.

Make sure to pick query, followed by as, and finally ticket.
